5. HEX inflation that could ever see market is even lower still because the staking mechanism keeps so much supply from being sold.
4. HEX inflation is lower than 3.69% always, because it's not paid on un-minted rewards, nor stakes that have good accounting run on them instead of end stake.
3. HEX inflation is only credited to those that can't sell it (stakers.) And stakes avg. 4 years long, so it's quite delayed.
2. HEX has lower inflation at a max of 3.69% than Bitcoin had in it's first 10 years.

People keep asking about inflation in #HEX.\n1. HEX has basically less than 0% inflation to the staker class on average. Since they're being paid the inflation on all minted coins, and not everyone is a member of the class.

Exchange affiliate programs pay only a percent on fees, and fees are only a percent. So basically you'd make some percent of some percent. Instead of 20% on the whole stack plus 20% of a 10% bonus to the user as well.

Basically, just like you didn't think #Bitcoin and #Ethereum could drop 40 and 50 percent in day, violate the longest term trendline, etc. You probably also don't think it can keep going down and down eating through thick bid walls bouncing a bit, then continuing to drill down.
This will have side affects latter, such as ever increasing prices again when the crisis is over. Cryptocurrencies thrive in that type of inflationary, risk-on environment.

These types of events do tend to happen every decade or so, cyclically. Some think we've been overdue. Government money printing can ease the pain, and improve the outcomes by stepping in and helping markets function and provide businesses the credit they need to function.

Everyone will be looking for cash to pay the bills, people and companies alike. This will lead to continued selling pressure and decreasing prices for most assets, as you've seen, when people need money they sell anything and everything.
